item.title: scientific method
item.description: In her review of a book by Henry Cowles on the history of the scientific method, Henry M. Cowles, The Scientific Method: An Evolution of Thinking from Darwin to Dewey Jessica Riskin recounts that the word “scientist” was coined in 1834 as a joke by William Whewell in his “excruciatingly patronizing” review of Mary Somerville’s book On the Connexion of the Physical Sciences. Whewell lamented “the lack of a general name for those who studied the material world,” and, after rejecting several alternatives, settled on scientist.

item.title: classical worldview
item.description: The term “classical worldview” is broadly used to describe the scientific description of the world that began with Greek philosophers and reached its zenith in the 19th century. It was conceived 2,500 years ago as a rational replacement of myths about gods who controlled the world by imposing their whims through acts of nature they caused.
